metadata.h1: How I Used AWS Lambda To Make My Girlfriend Smile
metadata.description: We are in the midst of some unprecedented times at the moment. COVID-19 has taken over, and the only way we can help is to lock ourselves inside. Unless you are quarantining alone, it is possible…

all_paragraphs: We are in the midst of some unprecedented times at the moment. COVID-19 has taken over, and the only way we can help is to lock ourselves inside.
Unless you are quarantining alone, it is possible that you may have lost your patience with those around you (or they have lost their patience with you).
It may be time we spread some happiness.
What better way to spread happiness than to have an inanimate object do it for you?
We will be programming an Alexa skill to make our Amazon device say some customized funny things.

The introvert in me loved this exercise. It not only gave me tremendous exposure to some cutting edge technology but also brought a smile to the faces of those around me. In these trying times, I think we could all use a smile.

We are using a style of comedy called “shock humor” here. When somebody hears their name coupled with a compliment coming from an inanimate object when they least expect it, it is sure to leave them in tears of laughter for minutes to come.
No programming ability is expected of you in this tutorial (although it certainly helps). Just the ability to follow directions is truly all you need.
Make your girlfriend, boyfriend, son, daughter, husband, wife, sister, brother, aunt, uncle, dog laugh today!
Create an Alexa skill to spread positivity.
You will need the following items to get started on this tutorial:
Log into your AWS account and navigate to AWS Lambda which you will find under the Compute section:
Then we will click on the Create Function button inside of the AWS Lambda dashboard:

For this Lambda function, we are going to use a Serverless App Repository created by somebody else. These repositories are created by AWS, AWS partners and other developers and are made readily available for us.
If you are not seeing any Alexa skill-related options, try switching your region to us-east-1. That is what I am using.
Next, click on the alexa-skills-kit-nodejs-factskill card above.
After clicking that link, leave all settings to the default. However, I will change the application name to something else:
Once you’ve finished configuring your settings for the function, click the deploy button in the bottom right-hand corner.
CloudFormation will take care of this deploy.
After a few minutes, you will see this:
Now, when you get to AWS Lambda Functions (on the navbar on the left-hand side), you will see your newly created function.
Click on your newly created function link.
Now, this is where it gets fun.
Once you are inside your Lambda function, you can scroll down to the text editor in Function Code.
Search for this block of code. This is the version for English speakers. Choose whatever language you speak in:
We must edit the GET_FACT_MESSAGE field and the FACTSarray as an absolute bare minimum to get this working the way we want it to. Feel free to edit anything else:

You’ll notice that I took everything out of the FACTS array. This is because this specific Alexa skill is designed to select an element randomly from the array to say. When there is only one element in the array, there is only one option for it to say :)
Put whatever you want into these fields. Have some fun with it!
Okay, now that is all we need to do from the Lambda side. Let’s make it so we can use this with the Alexa device in our home.
Navigate to https://developer.amazon.com/alexa/console/ask; this is where we are going to create the actual skill for our Alexa. We are going to create a developer account.
If you are not already registered, use the same account you have your Amazon Alexa registered to. That will make this process a whole lot easier.
If you don’t have your Alexa registered to your Amazon account, it’s straightforward to do so. Just download the Alexa app on your phone and follow the steps.
Once you are at https://developer.amazon.com/alexa/console/ask, click the Create Skill button on the right-hand side:
Then give it a name, and leave Custom selected as the model to add our skill and Provision your own as the method to host our skills backend resources:
Then we will change our template to Fact Skill as this is how we generated our Lambda function.
Once you hit Choose, our Alexa app is created! It’s that easy.
Now, this step is essential. We must change our endpoint to be the endpoint from our AWS Lambda function. Otherwise, how will it know which Lambda function to trigger?
Go back to your Lambda function in AWS and look for the ARN at the top right-hand corner:
Copy that to your clipboard, and paste it in the Default Region field of the Endpoint tab:
Click the Save Endpoints button at the top.

Now we need to add a new Intent. This is what you need to say to your Alexa for it to trigger your Lambda function. So you’ll see below that I’ve entered, “what do I think of tara.” Tara is the name of my girlfriend; you can make this anything.
This utterance is what you will need to say to your Alexa device for it to respond with what you wrote in the AWS Lambda function code.
Once you’ve added all of the utterances you want your Alexa to respond to, click Save Model and Build Model. This should just take a couple of seconds or minutes to build.
You should then see this message appear at the bottom when the build has succeeded:
Now navigate to the Test tab in the top navbar.
Change Skill testing is enabled dropdown to Development.
Type in your utterance on the left-hand side, and your Lambda function should be triggered, and your response will be outputted.
Now, if your Alexa device is registered to your account, you can say the utterance to your device, and the same response will be returned, but this time from Alexa.
And that’s all folks. Hopefully, you used this to make somebody laugh. There is so much you can do with these Alexa skills; we just merely skimmed the surface.
